facts.text: Civil Appeal No. 408 of 1957

anchor.surface_text: Civil Appeal No. 408 of 1957. Appeal by Special Leave from the Judgment and Order dated the 28th September, 1955, of the former Bombay High Court in Income-tax Reference No. 5 of 1955.

facts.text: Appeal by Special Leave from the Judgment and Order dated the 28th September, 1955, of the former Bombay High Court in Income-tax Reference No. 5 of 1955

anchor.surface_text: Appeal by Special Leave from the Judgment and Order dated the 28th September, 1955, of the former Bombay High Court in Income-tax Reference No. 5 of 1955. Sanat P. Mehta, S. N. Andley, J. B. Dadachanji, Rameshwar Nath and P. L. Vohra, for the appellant.

facts.text: Judgment of the Court delivered by SHAH J. on October 18, 1960

anchor.surface_text: 1960. October 18. The Judgment of the Court was delivered by SHAH J.-To the appellant who was a non-resident for the purposes of the Indian Income Tax Act, 1922, had accrued in the assessment years 1943-44, 1944-45, 1946-47 and 1947-48 certain dividend income within the taxable territory of British India,

facts.text: Appellant was a non-resident for the purposes of the Indian Income Tax Act, 1922

anchor.surface_text: To the appellant who was a non-resident for the purposes of the Indian Income Tax Act, 1922, had accrued in the assessment years 1943-44, 1944-45, 1946-47 and 1947-48 certain dividend income within the taxable territory of British India, but the appellant did not submit returns of his income for those assessment years.

facts.text: Certain dividend income accrued to the appellant in the assessment years 1943-44, 1944-45, 1946-47 and 1947-48 within the taxable territory of British India

anchor.surface_text: To the appellant who was a non-resident for the purposes of the Indian Income Tax Act, 1922, had accrued in the assessment years 1943-44, 1944-45, 1946-47 and 1947-48 certain dividend income within the taxable territory of British India, but the appellant did not submit returns of his income for those assessment years.

facts.text: Appellant did not submit returns of his income for assessment years 1943-44, 1944-45, 1946-47 and 1947-48

anchor.surface_text: but the appellant did not submit returns of his income for those assessment years. In exercise of his powers under s. 34 of the Indian Income Tax Act, 1922, the Income Tax Officer, Bombay City, served upon the appellant notices under s. 34 read with s, 22 2  of the Act for assessment of tax in respect of those years.

facts.text: Income Tax Officer, Bombay City, served notice under s.34 read with s.22(2) for 1943-44 on March 27, 1952

anchor.surface_text: The notice for the year 1943-44 was served on the appellant on March 27, 1952, for the year 1944-45 on February 16, 1953, for the year 1946-47 on April 4, 1951 and for the year 1947-48 on April 2, 1952.

facts.text: Notice for 1944-45 served on February 16, 1953

anchor.surface_text: for the year 1944-45 on February 16, 1953, for the year 1946-47 on April 4, 1951 and for the year 1947-48 on April 2, 1952. The Income Tax Officer completed the assessments in respect of the years 1943-44, 1944 45 and 1947-48 on May 6, 1953 and for the year 1946-47 on March 19, 1952.

facts.text: Notice for 1946-47 served on April 4, 1951

anchor.surface_text: for the year 1946-47 on April 4, 1951 and for the year 1947-48 on April 2, 1952. The Income Tax Officer completed the assessments in respect of the years 1943-44, 1944 45 and 1947-48 on May 6, 1953 and for the year 1946-47 on March 19, 1952.

facts.text: Notice for 1947-48 served on April 2, 1952

anchor.surface_text: and for the year 1947-48 on April 2, 1952. The Income Tax Officer completed the assessments in respect of the years 1943-44, 1944 45 and 1947-48 on May 6, 1953 and for the year 1946-47 on March 19, 1952. The orders of assessment were confirmed by the Appellate Assistant Commissioner and by the Income Tax Appellate Tribunal.

facts.text: Income Tax Officer completed assessments for 1943-44, 1944-45 and 1947-48 on May 6, 1953

anchor.surface_text: The Income Tax Officer completed the assessments in respect of the years 1943-44, 1944 45 and 1947-48 on May 6, 1953 and for the year 1946-47 on March 19, 1952. The orders of assessment were confirmed by the Appellate Assistant Commissioner and by the Income Tax Appellate Tribunal.

facts.text: Assessment for 1946-47 completed on March 19, 1952

anchor.surface_text: and for the year 1946-47 on March 19, 1952. The orders of assessment were confirmed by the Appellate Assistant Commissioner and by the Income Tax Appellate Tribunal. At the instance of the appellant, the Income Tax Appellate Tribunal drew up a statement of the case under s. 66 1  of the Income Tax Act and submitted to the High Court of Judicature at Bombay the following two questions

facts.text: Orders of assessment confirmed by Appellate Assistant Commissioner and Income Tax Appellate Tribunal

anchor.surface_text: The orders of assessment were confirmed by the Appellate Assistant Commissioner and by the Income Tax Appellate Tribunal. At the instance of the appellant, the Income Tax Appellate Tribunal drew up a statement of the case under s. 66 1  of the Income Tax Act and submitted to the High Court of Judicature at Bombay the following two questions

facts.text: At instance of appellant, Income Tax Appellate Tribunal drew up statement of case under s.66(1) and submitted to Bombay High Court

anchor.surface_text: At the instance of the appellant, the Income Tax Appellate Tribunal drew up a statement of the case under s. 66 1  of the Income Tax Act and submitted to the High Court of Judicature at Bombay the following two questions  I . Whether the notices issued under s. 22 2  of the Act read with s. 34 of the Act for the assessment years 1943-44, 1944-45, 1946-47 and 1947-48 were served after the period of limitation prescribed by s. 34 of the Act?

facts.text: Bombay High Court answered first question in the negative and second did not arise

anchor.surface_text: The High Court answered the first question in the negative and observed that on that answer, the second question did not arise . With special leave under Art. 136 of the Constitution, this appeal is preferred by the appellant against the order of the High Court.

facts.text: Appeal to Supreme Court preferred by appellant with special leave under Article 136 of the Constitution

anchor.surface_text: With special leave under Art. 136 of the Constitution, this appeal is preferred by the appellant against the order of the High Court. The only question which falls to be determined in this appeal is whether the proceedings for assessment were commenced within the period of limitation prescribed for serving notice of assessment under s. 34 1  a  of the Act.

facts.text: Notices issued by Income Tax Officer for the years in question were issued within eight years from the end of the years of assessment

anchor.surface_text: Admittedly, the notices issued by the Income Tax Officer for the years in question were issued within eight years from the end of the years of assessment and if cl. 1 a  of s. 34 applied, the assessment was not barred by the law of limitation.

facts.text: Appellant contended that notices were governed by cl.(1)(b) of s.34 not cl.(1)(a)

anchor.surface_text: But the appellant contended that the notices for assessment were, even though he had not made a return of his income for the years in question, governed not by cl. 1 a  of s. 34, but by cl. 1 b  of s. 34.

facts.text: Appellant was resident outside the taxable territory in the years of assessment

anchor.surface_text: He contended that being a resident outside the taxable territory in the years of , assessment, a general notice under s. 22 1  did not give rise to a liability to submit a return, and his inaction did not amount to omission or failure to submit a return, inviting the applicability of s. 34 1 a .

facts.text: Income accrued in taxable territory and exceeded maximum not chargeable to income-tax

anchor.surface_text: To the appellant though non-resident income had admittedly accrued in the taxable territory and that income exceeded the maximum amount not chargeable to income-tax., The appellant not having submitted a return in pursuance of the notice issued under s.221 the Income Tax Officer was competent under s. 34 1 a  to issue notice at any time within eight years of the end of the year of assessment for assessing him to tax.

facts.text: Court held that proceedings for assessment were commenced within limitation under s.34(1)(a)

anchor.surface_text: The High Court was therefore right in holding that the proceedings for assessment were properly commenced within the period of limitation prescribed by s. 34 1 a  from the close of the year of assessment.
With special leave under Art. 136 of the Constitution, this appeal is preferred by the appellant against the order of the High Court.

anchor.surface_text: If the answer to Question No. 1 is in the affirmative, whether the assessments for the years in question were invalid in law? The High Court answered the first question in the negative

anchor.surface_text: The only question which falls to be determined in this appeal is whether the proceedings for assessment were companymenced within the period of limitation prescribed for serving numberice of assessment under s. 34 1  a  of the Act.

arguments.court_reasoning: s.34(1)(a) applies as there was omission to file return under s.22(1) which binds non-residents

arguments.claim: being a non-resident outside taxable territory, general notice under s.22(1) did not create liability to submit return and inaction not omission or failure under s.34(1)(a)

anchor.surface_text: He contended that being a resident outside the taxable territory in the years of , assessment, a general notice under s. 22 1  did not give rise to a liability to submit a return, and his inaction did not amount to omission or failure to submit a return, inviting the applicability of s. 34 1  a .

arguments.court_reasoning: s.22(1) expression 'every person' includes non-residents liable to tax with no exemption in section or context

arguments.claim: omission or failure to make return for non-resident arises only if no return filed after individual notice under s.22(2)

anchor.surface_text: He submitted that omission or failure to make a return can only arise qua a non-resident, if no return is filed after service of an individual notice under s. 22 2 .

court_response_anchor.surface_text: r. 18 requires every person who has taxable income to submit his return, and if he fails to do so, under s. 34 of the Act the Income Tax Officer may c

arguments.court_reasoning: s.22(2) is additional power, does not derogate from general obligation under s.22(1)

arguments.claim: notice under s.22(1) imposes obligation only on residents within taxable territory not non-residents, supported by s.1(2)

anchor.surface_text: In other words, the plea is that a notice under s. 22 1  imposes an obligation upon persons resident within the taxable territory and not upon non-residents, and support for this argument is sought to be obtained from s. 1 sub-s.  2  which extended the Income Tax Act at the material time to British India.

court_response_anchor.surface_text: ncome Tax Officer was companypetent under s. 34 1  a  to issue numberice at any time within eight years of the end of the year of assessment for asses

arguments.court_reasoning: difficult to imply unexpressed limitation excluding non-residents from general provisions when power to tax granted within territory

arguments.claim: s.22(1) 'every person whose total income... not chargeable' includes all liable to tax, nothing exempts non-residents from submitting return

anchor.surface_text: The expression every person whose total income during the previous year exceeded the maximum amount which is not chargeable to income-tax in s. 22 1  includes all persons who are liable to pay tax and there is nothing in the section or in its context which exempts non-residents from liability to submit a return pursuant to a notice thereunder.

arguments.claim: non-resident may not know of general notice under s.22(1) irrelevant, plain words must be given effect

anchor.surface_text: The fact that a non-resident assessee may not come to know of the general notice issued under s. 22 1  is not a ground for not giving effect to the plain words used in the section.

arguments.claim: s.22(1) read with r.18 requires every person with taxable income to submit return, failure allows s.34(1)(a)

anchor.surface_text: In terms, the clause read with r. 18 requires every person who has taxable income to submit his return, and if he fails to do so, under s. 34 of the Act the Income Tax Officer may commence proceedings for assessment within the period prescribed by cl.  1  a .

arguments.claim: s.34(1)(b) applies only where no omission or failure to make return or disclose

anchor.surface_text: Section 34 1  b  applies only to those cases where there is no omission or failure to make a return of the income or to make a full and true disclosure of facts material to the assessment.

arguments.claim: Income Tax Officer competent under s.34(1)(a) to issue notice within 8 years as appellant non-resident had accrued income exceeding exemption, no return submitted under s.22(1)

anchor.surface_text: To the appellant though non-resident income had admittedly accrued in the taxable territory and that income exceeded the maximum amount not chargeable to income-tax. The appellant not having submitted a return in pursuance of the notice issued under s.221 the Income Tax Officer was competent under s. 34 1  a  to issue notice at any time within eight years of the end of the year of assessment for assessing him to tax.

arguments.claim: once notice under s.22(1) given by publication, every person with income over exemption obliged to return, non-submission is omission under s.34(1)(a)

anchor.surface_text: Once a notice is given by publication in the press and in the prescribed manner under s. 22 1 , every person whose income exceeds the maximum amount exempt from tax is obliged to submit a return and if he does not do so, it will be deemed that there was omission on his part to make a return within the meaning of s. 34 1  a .

arguments.claim: no warrant for s.22(1) applying only to residents, obligation for non-resident only after s.22(2)

anchor.surface_text: There is no warrant for the submission that s. 22 1  applies to residents only and that an obligation to make a return on the part of a non-resident can only arise if a notice under sub-s.  2  is served.

arguments.claim: s.22(2) allows special notice but does not derogate from liability under s.22(1)

anchor.surface_text: Under sub-s.  2  it is open to the Income Tax Officer to serve a special notice upon any person requiring him to furnish a return in the prescribed form, but that provision does not derogate from the liability arising under sub-s.  1  to submit a return.

arguments.claim: if power to tax income in territory granted by s.1(2), general provisions like s.22(1) apply without unexpressed limit to residents only

anchor.surface_text: The Income Tax Act extends by s. 1 2  to the taxable territory and not beyond but within that territory, the Income Tax Officer has power to tax income which accrues, arises or is received, and that is not disputed by the appellant. If power to tax be granted, it is difficult to appreciate the ground on which the plea that the general provision imposing liability upon persons receiving taxable income is subject to an unexpressed limitation that it is to apply only to residents and not to non-residents.

arguments.claim: no need for special s.22(2) notice to non-resident before deeming omission under s.34(1)(a), no express or implied provision

anchor.surface_text: The submission that a person liable to pay tax but resident outside the taxable territory must be served with a special notice under s. 22 2  before his inaction in the matter of making a return may be deemed omission within the meaning of s. 34 1  is without force. There is no such express provision made by the statute and none can be implied from the context.

arguments.claim: proceedings commenced within limitation under s.34(1)(a)

anchor.surface_text: The High Court was therefore right in holding that the proceedings for assessment were properly commenced within the period of limitation prescribed by s. 34 1  a  from the close of the year of assessment.

holdings.text: The proceedings for assessment were properly commenced within the period of limitation prescribed by s. 34(1)(a) from the close of the year of assessment

anchor.surface_text: The High Court was therefore right in holding that the proceedings for assessment were properly commenced within the period of limitation prescribed by s. 34 1  a  from the close of the year of assessment.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Notices issued within 8 years; appellant's failure to file return under s.22(1) triggers s.34(1)(a) even for non-residents

holdings.text: Section 34(1)(b) applies only to those cases where there is no omission or failure to make a return of the income or to make a full and true disclosure of facts material to the assessment

anchor.surface_text: Section 34 1  b  applies only to those cases where there is no omission or failure to make a return of the income or to make a full and true disclosure of facts material to the assessment.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Distinguishes (1)(a) for omission cases from (1)(b) for information-based escapes without omission

holdings.text: The expression 'every person whose total income... exceeded the maximum amount which is not chargeable to income-tax' in s.22(1) includes all persons who are liable to pay tax and there is nothing which exempts non-residents from liability to submit a return

anchor.surface_text: The expression every person whose total income during the previous year exceeded the maximum amount which is number chargeable to income-tax in s. 22 1  includes all persons who are liable to pay tax and there is numberhing in the section or in its companytext which exempts number-residents from liability to submit a return pursuant to a numberice thereunder.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Plain language of s.22(1) binds non-residents with taxable income in territory; no exemption implied

holdings.text: Once a notice is given by publication under s.22(1), every person whose income exceeds the maximum exempt amount is obliged to submit a return and non-submission is omission under s.34(1)(a)

holdings.reasoning_summary: General notice binds all; failure constitutes omission triggering 8-year limit under s.34(1)(a)

holdings.text: There is no warrant for s.22(1) applying only to residents; obligation for non-resident arises under s.22(1) without need for s.22(2) notice

anchor.surface_text: There is numberwarrant for the submission that s. 22 1  applies to residents only and that an obligation to make a return on the part of a numberresident can only arise if a numberice under sub-s.  2  is served.

holdings.reasoning_summary: No textual basis to limit s.22(1) to residents; s.22(2) is additional, not prerequisite

holdings.text: s.22(2) does not derogate from the liability under s.22(1) to submit a return

anchor.surface_text: Under sub-s.  2  it is open to the Income Tax Officer to serve a special numberice upon any person requiring him to furnish a return in the prescribed form, but that provision does number derogate from the liability arising under sub-s.  1  to submit a return.

holdings.reasoning_summary: s.22(2) provides optional individual notice; general obligation under s.22(1) stands independently

holdings.text: No special notice under s.22(2) required for non-resident before deeming omission under s.34(1)(a); no express or implied provision

anchor.surface_text: The submission that a person liable to pay tax but resident outside the taxable territory must be served with a special numberice under s. 22 2  before his inaction in the matter of making a return may be deemed omission within the meaning of s. 34 1  is without force. There is numbersuch express provision made by the statute and numbere can be implied from the companytext.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Statute lacks any requirement for individual notice to non-residents; general notice suffices

holdings.text: General provisions like s.22(1) apply to non-residents if power to tax income in territory is granted by s.1(2), without unexpressed limitations

anchor.surface_text: The Income Tax Act extends by s. 1 2  to the taxable territory and number beyond but within that territory, the Income Tax Officer has power to tax income which accrues, arises or is received, and that is number disputed by the appellant. If power to tax be granted, it is difficult to appreciate the ground on which the plea that the general provision imposing liability upon persons receiving taxable income is subject to an unexpressed limitation that it is to apply only to residents and number to number-residents.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Territorial tax power implies application of general machinery provisions to non-residents without implied exemptions
